com.gnahraf.util

Class TaskStack

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.util.TaskStack
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, Channel

    public class TaskStack
extends Object
implements Channel
    Utility for resource releasing. Mostly, this has to do with the fact that exception-safe code in Java ends up with a clutter of try/finally clauses. (Language envy: C++ shines here..)

    Example usage

    Java 1.6-

          TaskStack closer = new TaskStack();
      try {
          Lock a = ..
          a.lock();
          closer.pushUnlock(a);
          Lock b = ..
          
          if (!b.tryLock())
              return;
           
          FileChannel file = openFile();
          closer.pushClose(file);
          
          // do some work
          ..
      } finally {
          closer.close();
      }

    Java 1.7+

          try (TaskStack closer = new TaskStack()) {
          Lock a = ..
          a.lock();
          closer.pushUnlock(a);
          Lock b = ..
          
          if (!b.tryLock())
              return;
           
          FileChannel file = openFile();
          closer.pushClose(file);
          
          // do some work
          ..
      }
    Author:
    Babak

        public int pop()
        Pops the last pushed operation from the stack and executes (closes) it.
        Returns:
        the remaining number of operations on the stack, or -1 if the stack was empty

      • clear

        public TaskStack clear()
        Clears the stack. If there are any operations on the stack, they are discarded (ignored). This comes handy when the TaskStack is a clean-up-on-failure type of construct. For example, 
         try (TaskStack closeOnFail = new TaskStack()) {
      InputStream in = ..
      closeOnFail.pushClose(in);
       .
       .
      closeOnFail.pushClose(sock);
       .
       .
      // if we get this far, we're all good..
      closeOnFail.clear();
    }
